trans-unit.source: Title Page
Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Seas
An Underwater Tour of the World
JULES VERNE
Translated from the Original French by F.
trans-unit.note: This TU can be merged with the next 2 TUs, because they are in the same group.

trans-unit.source: P.
Walter
Text Prepared by:
F.
P.
Walter, 1433 Cedar Post, No. 31,
trans-unit.note: This TU cannot be merged with the next TU, because it is not in the same group (due to markup in the original source document).

trans-unit.source: Houston, Texas 77055.
A complete, unabridged translation of Vingt milles lieues sous les mers by Jules Verne, based on the original French texts published in Paris by J.
Hetzel et Cie.
over the period 1869-71.
VERNE'S TITLE
The French title of this novel is Vingt mille lieues sous les mers.
This is accurately translated as Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the SEAS—rather than the SEA, as with many English editions.
Verne's novel features a tour of the major oceans, and the term Leagues in its title is used as a measure not of depth but distance.
Ed.

header.note: The English source for this document is made available by the dita2indesign project, as a sample. See http://dita2indesign.sourceforge.net/dita_gutenberg_samples.html for more information.

trans-unit.source: Chapter 1 A Runaway Reef
trans-unit.target: Chapitre 1 Un écueil fuyant
trans-unit.note: French "translations" provided by Google. I'm sure they are fantastically accurate to the original French.
Is "écueil" is the right word for "Reef"?

trans-unit.source: THE YEAR 1866 was marked by a bizarre development, an unexplained and downright inexplicable phenomenon that surely no one has forgotten.
trans-unit.target: L'année 1866 a été marquée par un développement bizarre, un phénomène inexpliqué et inexplicable que sûrement carrément personne n'a oublié.
trans-unit.note: Original French, as found online: L’année 1866 fut marquée par un événement bizarre, un phénomène inexpliqué et inexplicable que personne n’a sans doute oublié.

alt-trans.source: THE YEAR 1866 was marked by a bizarre development, an unexplained and downright inexplicable phenomenon that surely no one has forgotten.
alt-trans.target: L’année 1866 fut marquée par un événement bizarre, un phénomène inexpliqué et inexplicable que personne n’a sans doute oublié.
alt-trans.note: This is a really old translation!
Translation is exact text match, but tags don't match.

trans-unit.source: Without getting into those rumors that upset civilians in the seaports and deranged the public mind even far inland, it must be said that professional seamen were especially alarmed.
trans-unit.target: Sans entrer dans les rumeurs selon lesquelles des civils bouleversé dans les ports maritimes et dérangé l'esprit du public, même loin dans les terres, il faut dire que les marins professionnels ont été particulièrement alarmé.
trans-unit.note: First alt-trans match has a 1/2 percent penalty for a tag mismatch.
2nd alt-trans match is a Machine Translation

alt-trans.source: Without getting into those rumors that upset civilians in the seaports and deranged the public mind even far inland, it must be said that professional seamen were especially alarmed.
alt-trans.target: Sans parler des rumeurs qui agitaient les populations des ports et surexcitaient l’esprit public à l’intérieur des continents les gens de mer furent particulièrement émus.

alt-trans.source: Without getting into those rumors that upset civilians in the seaports and deranged the public mind even far inland, it must be said that professional seamen were especially alarmed.
alt-trans.target: Sans parler des rumeurs qui agitaient les populations des ports et surexcitaient l’esprit public à l’intérieur des continents les gens de mer furent particulièrement émus.

trans-unit.source: Traders, shipowners, captains of vessels, skippers, and master mariners from Europe and America, naval officers from every country, and at their heels the various national governments on these two continents, were all extremely disturbed by the business.
trans-unit.target: Traders, les armateurs, les capitaines de navires, capitaines, et les capitaines de l'Europe et l'Amérique, officiers de marine de tous les pays, et sur leurs talons les différents gouvernements nationaux sur ces deux continents, ont tous été extrêmement troublé par l'entreprise.
trans-unit.note: alt-trans match is exact, in-context match (dx:glorious-match=yes)

alt-trans.source: Traders, shipowners, captains of vessels, skippers, and master mariners from Europe and America, naval officers from every country, and at their heels the various national governments on these two continents, were all extremely disturbed by the business.
alt-trans.target: Traders, les armateurs, les capitaines de navires, capitaines, et les capitaines de l'Europe et l'Amérique, officiers de marine de tous les pays, et sur leurs talons les différents gouvernements nationaux sur ces deux continents, ont tous été extrêmement troublé par l'entreprise.

trans-unit.source: In essence, over a period of time several ships had encountered "an enormous thing" at sea, a long spindle–shaped object, sometimes giving off a phosphorescent glow, infinitely bigger and faster than any whale.
trans-unit.target: En substance, sur une période de temps de plusieurs navires avaient rencontré «une chose énorme" en mer, un long objet en forme de fuseau, donnant parfois une lueur phosphorescente, infiniment plus grand et plus rapide que toute baleine.

trans-unit.source: The relevant data on this apparition, as recorded in various logbooks, agreed pretty closely as to the structure of the object or creature in question, its unprecedented speed of movement, its startling locomotive power, and the unique vitality with which it seemed to be gifted.
trans-unit.target: Les données pertinentes sur cette apparition, en tant que figurant dans les journaux différents, ont convenu d'assez près à la structure de l'objet ou la créature en question, sa vitesse de mouvement sans précédent, sa puissance surprenante de sa locomotion, la vie particulière dont il semblait être doué.

trans-unit.source: If it was a cetacean, it exceeded in bulk any whale previously classified by science.
trans-unit.target: Si c'était un cétacé, il a dépassé en vrac toute baleine déjà été classé par la science.

trans-unit.source: No naturalist, neither Cuvier nor Lacépède, neither Professor Dumeril nor Professor de Quatrefages, would have accepted the existence of such a monster sight unseen—specifically, unseen by their own scientific eyes.
trans-unit.target: Aucun naturaliste, ni Cuvier, ni Lacépède, ni professeur, ni Duméril professeur de Quatrefages, aurait accepté l'existence d'un tel spectacle monstre invisible plus précisément, sans être vus de leurs propres yeux scientifiques.

trans-unit.source: Striking an average of observations taken at different times—rejecting those timid estimates that gave the object a length of 200 feet, and ignoring those exaggerated views that saw it as a mile wide and three long—you could still assert that this phenomenal creature greatly exceeded the dimensions of anything then known to ichthyologists, if it existed at all.
trans-unit.target: Heurt une moyenne d'observations faites à des époques différentes, le rejet de ces estimations timide qui a donné l'objet d'une longueur de 200 pieds, et en ignorant ces opinions exagérées qui y ont vu un mile de large et trois à long on pouvait encore affirmer que cet être phénoménal dépassait de beaucoup les dimensions de quoi que ce soit alors connu ichtyologistes, si elle existait à tous.
trans-unit.note: This TU has an embedded Terminology hit

trans-unit.source: Now then, it did exist, this was an undeniable fact; and since the human mind dotes on objects of wonder, you can understand the worldwide excitement caused by this unearthly apparition.
trans-unit.target: Maintenant, il a existé, c'était un fait indéniable, et depuis l'adore esprit humain sur des objets d'émerveillement, vous pouvez comprendre l'excitation à travers le monde causé par cette apparition surnaturelle.

trans-unit.source: As for relegating it to the realm of fiction, that charge had to be dropped.
trans-unit.target: Quant à la rejeter au rang des fables, il fallait y renoncer.
trans-unit.note: This TU was translated manually (by copying from web page in this case). note the alt-trans which provides version history.

alt-trans.source: As for relegating it to the realm of fiction, that charge had to be dropped.
alt-trans.target: XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX

trans-unit.source: In essence, on July 20, 1866, the steamer Governor Higginson, from the Calcutta & Burnach Steam Navigation Co., encountered this moving mass five miles off the eastern shores of Australia.
trans-unit.target: XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX X
trans-unit.note: This TU has 2 embedded QA hits added by a tool at some point in the workflow. User or tool can delete QA hits from the file.

dx:qa-hit.dx:qa-shorttext: Date found in source, not found in target: "1866/07/20"

trans-unit.source: Captain Baker at first thought he was in the presence of an unknown reef; he was even about to fix its exact position when two waterspouts shot out of this inexplicable object and sprang hissing into the air some 150 feet.
trans-unit.target: XXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX X

trans-unit.source: So, unless this reef was subject to the intermittent eruptions of a geyser, the Governor Higginson had fair and honest dealings with some aquatic mammal, until then unknown, that could spurt from its blowholes waterspouts mixed with air and steam.
trans-unit.target: XXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXX

trans-unit.source: Similar events were likewise observed in Pacific seas, on July 23 of the same year, by the Christopher Columbus from the West India & Pacific Steam Navigation Co.
trans-unit.target: XX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXX

trans-unit.source: Consequently, this extraordinary cetacean could transfer itself from one locality to another with startling swiftness, since within an interval of just three days, the Governor Higginson and the Christopher Columbus had observed it at two positions on the charts separated by a distance of more than 700 nautical leagues.
trans-unit.target: XX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX X

trans-unit.source: Fifteen days later and 2,000 leagues farther, the Helvetia from the Compagnie Nationale and the Shannon from the Royal Mail line, running on opposite tacks in that part of the Atlantic lying between the United States and Europe, respectively signaled each other that the monster had been sighted in latitude 42° 15' north and longitude 60° 35' west of the meridian of Greenwich.
trans-unit.target: XXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX X

trans-unit.source: From their simultaneous observations, they were able to estimate the mammal's minimum length at more than 350 English feet; this was because both the Shannon and the Helvetia were of smaller dimensions, although each measured 100 meters stem to stern.
trans-unit.target: XXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX 350 XXXXX; XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX Shannon XXXX XXXX Helvetia XXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX.

trans-unit.source: Now then, the biggest whales, those rorqual whales that frequent the waterways of the Aleutian Islands, have never exceeded a length of 56 meters—if they reach even that.
trans-unit.target: XX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX

trans-unit.source: Author's Note: About 106 meters. An English foot is only 30.4 centimeters.
trans-unit.target: XXX XXXX: XXXX XXXXX XXXXX X

trans-unit.source: One after another, reports arrived that would profoundly affect public opinion:
trans-unit.target: XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX X

trans-unit.source: new observations taken by the transatlantic liner Pereire, the Inman line's Etna running afoul of the monster, an official report drawn up by officers on the French frigate Normandy, dead–earnest reckonings obtained by the general staff of Commodore Fitz–James aboard the Lord Clyde.
trans-unit.target: XXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXX

trans-unit.source: In lighthearted countries, people joked about this phenomenon, but such serious, practical countries as England, America, and Germany were deeply concerned.
trans-unit.target: XX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXX

trans-unit.source: In every big city the monster was the latest rage; they sang about it in the coffee houses, they ridiculed it in the newspapers, they dramatized it in the theaters.
trans-unit.target: X XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX

trans-unit.source: The tabloids found it a fine opportunity for hatching all sorts of hoaxes.
trans-unit.target: XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXX

trans-unit.source: In those newspapers short of copy, you saw the reappearance of every gigantic imaginary creature, from "Moby Dick," that dreadful white whale from the High Arctic regions, to the stupendous kraken whose tentacles could entwine a 500–ton craft and drag it into the ocean depths.
trans-unit.target: XX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX

trans-unit.source: They even reprinted reports from ancient times:
trans-unit.target: XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX

trans-unit.source: the views of Aristotle and Pliny accepting the existence of such monsters, then the Norwegian stories of Bishop Pontoppidan, the narratives of Paul Egede, and finally the reports of Captain Harrington—whose good faith is above suspicion—in which he claims he saw, while aboard the Castilian in 1857, one of those enormous serpents that, until then, had frequented only the seas of France's old extremist newspaper, The Constitutionalist.
trans-unit.target: XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX

trans-unit.source: An interminable debate then broke out between believers and skeptics in the scholarly societies and scientific journals.
trans-unit.target: XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX

trans-unit.source: The "monster question" inflamed all minds.
trans-unit.target: XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX

trans-unit.source: During this memorable campaign, journalists making a profession of science battled with those making a profession of wit, spilling waves of ink and some of them even two or three drops of blood, since they went from sea serpents to the most offensive personal remarks.
trans-unit.target: XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX

trans-unit.source: For six months the war seesawed.
trans-unit.target: XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX X

dx:utx-term.dx:utx-comment: I have no idea if this is correct, but let's pretend it is for the sake of this example.
If this is used, it should be flagged.
A person who devotes a career to studying some of the estimated 25,000 to 30,000 species of bony fishes, sharks, rays, and lobe-finned fishes
